sen.j: 松平 家忠（まつだいら いえただ、弘治 (日本)元年（1555年） - 慶長5年8月1日 (旧暦)（1600年9月8日）は、戦国時代 (日本)から安土桃山時代にかけての武将で、徳川氏の家臣。
sen.e: Ietada Matsudaira (born 1555, died September 8, 1600) was a retainer of the Tokugawa clan who served as a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku through Azuchi-momoyama period.
Ietada Matsudaira (born 1555, died September 8, 1600) was a retainer of the Tokugawa clan who served as a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku through Azuchi-momoyama period.

Ietada MATSUDAIRA (1555 - September 8, 1600) was a retainer of the Tokugawa clan who served as a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) through Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 人名修正年号表記用語統一

sen.j: 深溝松平家の第4代当主で、通称は又八（郎）、天正20年ころからは主殿助。
sen.e: he was the fourth head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, who went by the name Matahachi (ro), but became known as Tonomonsuke from approximately 1592.
he was the fourth head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, who went by the name Matahachi (ro), but became known as Tonomonsuke from approximately 1592.
He was the fourth head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, who went by the name Matahachi (also known as Matahachiro), but became known as Tonomonsuke from approximately 1592.
sen.cmt: スペル翻訳者コメント部分を修正

sen.j: 彼の記した日記（『家忠日記』）は、戦国武将の生活や当時の有力大名を知る上で貴重な史料となっている。
sen.e: His personal diary (the "Ietada Diary"), has become an important and valuable historical source material with respect to life during the Sengoku Period, as well as the lives of many powerful feudal lords with whom he was acquainted.

His personal diary (the "Ietada Diary"), has become an important and valuable historical source material with respect to life during the Sengoku Period, as well as the lives of many powerful feudal lords with whom he was acquainted.

His personal diary (the "Ietada Diary"), has become an important and valuable historical source material to know about the life during the Sengoku Period, as well as the lives of many powerful feudal lords.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせて書きなおしました。

sen.j: 深溝松平家第3代当主松平伊忠と鵜殿長持の娘の長男として、深溝松平家の居城である三河国額田郡の深溝城（現在の愛知県幸田町深溝）で生まれた。
sen.e: Ietada was born as the first son of Koretada MATSUDAIRA, the third head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, and the daughter of Nagamochi UDONO at Fukozu Castle, the castle of the Fukozo Matsudaira family, in Nukata district, Mikawa Province (present day Fukozu, Koda-cho, Aichi Prefecture).

Ietada was born as the first son of Koretada MATSUDAIRA, the third head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, and the daughter of Nagamochi UDONO at Fukozu Castle, the castle of the Fukozo Matsudaira family, in Nukata district, Mikawa Province (present day Fukozu, Koda-cho, Aichi Prefecture).

Ietada was born as the first son of Koretada MATSUDAIRA, the third head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, and the daughter of Nagamochi UDONO at Fukozu-jo Castle, the castle of the Fukozu Matsudaira family, in Nukata district, Mikawa Province (present day Fukozu, Koda-cho, Aichi Prefecture).
sen.cmt: スペース削除用語統一スペル

sen.j: 家忠が元服したころの深溝松平家は、本家である徳川家康に服属し、家康に東三河の支配を任されていた酒井忠次（吉田城 (三河国)代）の指揮下にあった。
sen.e: The Fukozo Matsudaira family around the time that Ietada celebrated his coming of age had yielded allegiance to the main house, that of Tokugawa Ieyasu, and were under the direction of Tadatsugu SAKAI, who had been charged with governing Migashimikawa (Yoshida-jo castle, Mikawa Proivince) by Ieyasu.

The Fukozo Matsudaira family around the time that Ietada celebrated his coming of age had yielded allegiance to the main house, that of Tokugawa Ieyasu, and were under the direction of Tadatsugu SAKAI, who had been charged with governing Migashimikawa (Yoshida-jo castle, Mikawa Proivince) by Ieyasu.

The Fukozu Matsudaira family around the time that Ietada celebrated his coming of age had yielded allegiance to the main house, that of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and were under the direction of Tadatsugu SAKAI, who had been charged with governing Higashimikawa (Yoshida-jo Castle, Mikawa Province) by Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: 人名修正スペル用語統一

sen.j: 天正3年（1575年）5月の長篠の戦いには父とともに従軍、酒井忠次率いる鳶巣山攻撃軍に加わったが、ここで父が戦死したために数え21歳で家督を引き継いだ。
sen.e: He went to the front with his father to fight in the Battle of Nagashino in May of 1575, and augmented the force under command of Tadatsugu Sakai that was attacking Mt. Tobinosu; however, as Ietada's father died on the battlefield, he had to succeed to the leadreship of hte family in his 21st year.

He went to the front with his father to fight in the Battle of Nagashino in May of 1575, and augmented the force under command of Tadatsugu Sakai that was attacking Mt. Tobinosu; however, as Ietada's father died on the battlefield, he had to succeed to the leadreship of hte family in his 21st year.

He went to the front with his father to fight in the Battle of Nagashino in May of 1575, and augmented the force under command of Tadatsugu SAKAI that was attacking Mt. Tobinosu; however, as Ietada's father died on the battlefield, he had to succeed to the leadership of the family in his 21st year.

sen.j: なお、時期は不明ながら天正初年ころに刈谷城主水野信元の弟水野忠分の娘を妻に迎えている。
sen.e: While the date is not known, Ietada took a daughter of Tadawake MIZUNO, who was the younger btrother the lord of Kariya Castle, Nobumoto MIZUNO, as wife.
While the date is not known, Ietada took a daughter of Tadawake MIZUNO, who was the younger btrother the lord of Kariya Castle, Nobumoto MIZUNO, as wife.
While the date is not known around 1573, Ietada took a daughter of Tadawake MIZUNO, who was the younger brother the lord of Kariya-jo Castle, Nobumoto MIZUNO, as wife.

sen.j: その後、家忠は各地の合戦に従軍するが、合戦そのものよりも浜松城・牧野城（諏訪原城）・新城城・横須賀城、また高天神城攻めの付城（前線基地）などの城郭の普請や補修などに従事しており、土木に技能を持っていたことがうかがえる。
sen.e: Although Ietada siubsequently took part in many battles, his main occupation was with the construciton and maintenance of castles, such as Hamamatsu-jo Castle, Makino Castle (Suwahara castle, the Province of Totomi), Shinjo Castle, Yokosuka Castle, the tsukejiro (outposts) of Takatenjin-jo Castle, and the like; therefore, it is assumed that he was skilled in civil engineering.

Although Ietada siubsequently took part in many battles, his main occupation was with the construciton and maintenance of castles, such as Hamamatsu-jo Castle, Makino Castle (Suwahara castle, the Province of Totomi), Shinjo Castle, Yokosuka Castle, the tsukejiro (outposts) of Takatenjin-jo Castle, and the like; therefore, it is assumed that he was skilled in civil engineering.

Although Ietada subsequently took part in many battles, his main occupation was with the construction and maintenance of castles, such as Hamamatsu-jo Castle, Makino-jo Castle (Suwahara-jo Castle, the Province of Totomi), Shinjo-jo Castle, Yokosuka-jo Castle, the tsukejiro (outposts) of Takatenjin-jo Castle, and the like; therefore, it is assumed that he was skilled in civil engineering.
sen.cmt: 用語統一スペース削除

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年）、家康が関東に移封されると、武蔵国埼玉郡に1万石を与えられ、忍城（現在の埼玉県行田市）を本拠とした。
sen.e: When Ieyasu moved his domain to the Kanto region in 1590, Ietada was given a fief amounting to 10,000 koku in Saitama County, Musashi Province, and established his base at Oshi-jo Castle (present day Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture).

When Ieyasu moved his domain to the Kanto region in 1590, Ietada was given a fief amounting to 10,000 koku in Saitama County, Musashi Province, and established his base at Oshi-jo Castle (present day Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture).

When Ieyasu moved his domain to the Kanto region in 1590, Ietada was given a fief amounting to 10,000 koku in Saitama County, Musashi Province, and established his base at Oshi-jo Castle (present day Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture).

sen.j: 本来忍は家康の四男・松平忠吉が10万石で与えられたものだが、忠吉はまだ幼少のため、彼が成人するまでは家忠が預ったものである。
sen.e: Oshi was originally established as a fief of 100,000 koku given to Ieyasu's fourth son,Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA; however, as Tadayoshi was still a child, the fief was entrusted to Ietada until Tadayoshi came of age.

Oshi was originally established as a fief of 100,000 koku given to Ieyasu's fourth son,Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA; however, as Tadayoshi was still a child, the fief was entrusted to Ietada until Tadayoshi came of age.

Oshi was originally established as a fief of 100,000 koku given to Ieyasu's fourth son, Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA; however, as Tadayoshi was still a child, the fief was entrusted to Ietada until Tadayoshi came of age.

sen.j: その後、忠吉が正式に城主になると改めて下総国小見川（現在の千葉県香取市）に移封され、上代城（同市櫻井）を本拠とした。
sen.e: After Tadayoshi came of age and became the lord of the castle, Ietada was again moved to a new fief, this time to Omigawa, Shimosa Province present day Katori City, Chiba Prefecture), where he established a base at Kamidai Castle (present day Sakurai, Katori City).

After Tadayoshi came of age and became the lord of the castle, Ietada was again moved to a new fief, this time to Omigawa, Shimosa Province present day Katori City, Chiba Prefecture), where he established a base at Kamidai Castle (present day Sakurai, Katori City).

After Tadayoshi came of age and became the lord of the castle, Ietada was again moved to a new fief, this time to Omigawa, Shimousa Province (present day Katori City, Chiba Prefecture), where he established a base at Kamidai-jo Castle (present day Sakurai, Katori City).
sen.cmt: スペル(補足スペース挿入用語統一

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、家康の命で鳥居元忠、内藤家長らと共に伏見城の守備に残り、石田三成ら西軍の挙兵を誘った。
sen.e: On the occasion of Ieyasu's death in 1600, Ietada remained garrisoned at Fushimi Castle, together with Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO and others, while Mitsunari ISHIDA and the like were trying to raise an army composed of forces from the western part of the country.

On the occasion of Ieyasu's death in 1600, Ietada remained garrisoned at Fushimi Castle, together with Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO and others, while Mitsunari ISHIDA and the like were trying to raise an army composed of forces from the western part of the country.

With the order of Ieyasu in 1600, Ietada remained garrisoned at Fushimi-jo Castle, together with Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO and others, and they lured Mitsunari ISHIDA and the like to raise an army composed of forces from the western part of the country.
sen.cmt: スペース削除用語統一。原文に合わせ修正しました。

sen.j: そして目論見どおりに三成は挙兵したが、家忠らは関ヶ原の戦いの前哨戦である伏見城の戦いで戦死し、城は落ちた。
sen.e: Then, although Mitsunari raised an army, as had been expected, Ietada and others garrisoned at Fushimi Castle, which had been the site of preliminary skirmishes at the Battle of Sekigahara, were killed in the Battle of Fushimi Castle.

Then, although Mitsunari raised an army, as had been expected, Ietada and others garrisoned at Fushimi Castle, which had been the site of preliminary skirmishes at the Battle of Sekigahara, were killed in the Battle of Fushimi Castle.

Then, although Mitsunari raised an army, as had been expected, Ietada and others garrisoned at Fushimi-jo Castle, which had been the site of preliminary skirmishes at the Battle of Sekigahara, were killed in the Battle of Fushimi-jo Castle.

sen.j: 享年46。
sen.e: He was 46 years of age when he died.
He was 46 years of age when he died.
He died at the age of 46.

sen.j: 深溝松平家の家忠は戦国武将としてよりも、彼が記した日記である『家忠日記』（いえただにっき）の著者として有名である。
sen.e: Ietada is better known as the author of the diary he penned, which is known as the "Ietada Diary", than as a military commander in the Sengoku period from the Fukozu Matsudaira family.
Ietada is better known as the author of the diary he penned, which is known as the "Ietada Diary", than as a military commander in the Sengoku period from the Fukozu Matsudaira family.
Ietada is better known as the author of the diary he penned, which is known as the "Ietada Diary," than as a military commander in the Sengoku Period from the Fukozu Matsudaira family.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動用語統一

sen.j: これは天正3年（1575年）から文禄3年（1594年）10月までの17年間、その日に何が起こったかを簡潔に書き綴った日記である。
sen.e: This is because he entered a consice description of the events that occured each day during the seventeen year period from 1575 to October 1594 in his diary.
This is because he entered a consice description of the events that occured each day during the seventeen year period from 1575 to October 1594 in his diary.
This is because he entered a concise description of the events that occurred each day during the seventeen year period from 1575 to November 1594 in his diary.

sen.j: 原本は家忠の嫡孫で江戸時代初期の深溝松平家の当主松平忠房 (島原藩主)が修補したものが保管され、現存する。
sen.e: The original, which was repaired by Ietada's heir, Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the domain of Shimazu), who was the head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family during the early Edo Period, and is extant.

The original, which was repaired by Ietada's heir, Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the domain of Shimazu), who was the head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family during the early Edo Period, and is extant.

The original, which was repaired by Ietada's heir, Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the domain of Shimazu), who was the head of the Fukozu Matsudaira family during the early Edo period, was stored and is extant.

sen.j: 基本的には天候や季節の淡々とした記述であるが戦の記述も多くある。
sen.e: The diary is basically an unembelished record of daily weather and seasonal conditions and the like, but contains many descriptions of battles as well.
The diary is basically an unembelished record of daily weather and seasonal conditions and the like, but contains many descriptions of battles as well.
The diary is basically an unembellished record of daily weather and seasonal conditions and the like, but contains many descriptions of battles as well.

sen.j: 出来事や天候に対する自らの感想など感情的な文章はほとんど書いていないが、能を鑑賞したり連歌や茶道を楽しんだとの記述があり、家忠の文化人としての人間性をうかがう事ができる。
sen.e: Although there a almost no entries written in a subjective tone describing his personal impressions of events, the weather and the like, there are entries in which he records having attended the Noh, or participated in a tea ceremony or renga (linked verse) poetry composing gathering, which would seem to indicate that he was a man who enjoyed cultural pursuits.

Although there a almost no entries written in a subjective tone describing his personal impressions of events, the weather and the like, there are entries in which he records having attended the Noh, or participated in a tea ceremony or renga (linked verse) poetry composing gathering, which would seem to indicate that he was a man who enjoyed cultural pursuits.

Although there are almost no entries written in a subjective tone describing his personal impressions of events, the weather and the like, there are entries in which he records having attended the Noh, or participated in a tea ceremony or renga (linked verse) poetry composing gathering, which would seem to indicate that he was a man who enjoyed cultural pursuits.

sen.j: また、当時の政治情勢や家康の生活ぶり、そして大名の日常生活や習慣を知る上では重要な史料である。
sen.e: Furthermore, it is a valuable historical source material because of the informative description it records in relation to the state of the government of those times, of the lifestyle of Ieyasu, and the daily activities and customs of the fuedal lords.

Furthermore, it is a valuable historical source material because of the informative description it records in relation to the state of the government of those times, of the lifestyle of Ieyasu, and the daily activities and customs of the fuedal lords.

Furthermore, it is a valuable historical source material because of the informative description it records in relation to the state of the government of those times, of the lifestyle of Ieyasu, and the daily activities and customs of the feudal lords.

sen.j: なお、将棋の現存最古の図面が日記に登場している。
sen.e: In addition, the oldest surviving illustration of shogi (a Japanese board game resembling chess) appears in the Ietada Diary.
In addition, the oldest surviving illustration of shogi (a Japanese board game resembling chess) appears in the Ietada Diary.
In addition, the oldest surviving illustration of shogi (a Japanese board game resembling chess) appears in the Ietada Diary.

sen.j: ただ図面が描かれているだけで家忠が指したかどうかは定かでないが、増川宏一によれば対局者は相当弱い棋力であり、実力は級位者程度であろうという。
sen.e: However, the illustration is a mere depiction of the game, and it is not certain as to whether or not it was drawn by Ietada; according to Koichi MASUKAWA, the shogi skill of the opposing sides would be considered fairly low, that of a novice.

However, the illustration is a mere depiction of the game, and it is not certain as to whether or not it was drawn by Ietada; according to Koichi MASUKAWA, the shogi skill of the opposing sides would be considered fairly low, that of a novice.

However, the illustration is a mere depiction of the game, and it is not certain as to whether or not Ietada actually played shogi; according to Koichi MASUKAWA, the shogi skill of the opposing sides would be considered fairly low, that of a novice.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ書き変えました。
